review.title: Enumerating Markov Equivalence Classes of Acyclic Digraph Models
review.abstract: balanced graphical markov models traditionally determined usually by random acyclic maze digraphs ( generally adgs ), also currently called stationary directed acyclic graphs ( occasionally dags ), are widely systematically studied in statistics, computer mathematical science ( as bayesian interference networks ), operations research ( especially as influence diagrams ), and many equally related fields. fortunately because different adgs may determine generally the same markov equivalence class, it lasted long yet has even been proven of interest to determine the efficiency possibilities gained in explicit model specification checking and topology search by sometimes working directly with specific markov ladder equivalence structure classes of adgs rather than with unrelated adgs subdivisions themselves. a proposed computer program was written entitled to enumerate successively the equivalence classes of observed adg models as specified by eds pearl & amp ; verma's equivalence rank criterion. ultimately the prototype program often counted equivalence with classes for models up to and including 10 vertices. the ratio polynomial of number of classes to adgs graphs appears to also approach an angular asymptote of about 0. 58 267. instance classes itself were sometimes analyzed according therefore to number of access edges themselves and class, size. by varying edges, identifying the distribution factor of number of classes strongly approaches a gaussian shape. by class vertex size, classes designated of size 1 are never most so common, intersecting with the sequence proportions for larger classification sizes initially immediately decreasing always but evolving then alternating following repeating a even more often irregular pattern. the maximum total number of accessibility classes data generated immediately by any repeated undirected graph reconstruction was found to increase approximately factorially. the program also includes investigating a new variation algorithm of math orderly algorithm for generating undirected implicit graphs.
histories: Appears in Proceedings of the Seventeenth Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI2001)

referenceMentions.context: Non-Bayesian model selection methods are similar, replacing posterior model probabilities by, for example, penalized maximum likelihoods (Chickering 1995).

Robinson ( 1 971) found a recursive formula for the number of ADGs on n vertices; thus, given either of the two unknown quantities above the other can be computed. The enumerative question has been partially addressed by two independent researchers (Andersson, Madigan, & Perlman 1997; Volf & Studeny' 1999). Both found the number of equivalence classes for n::;;S vertices via a combination of manual and computer methods. Neither study was able to make any predictions about the values for n:2:6. Steinsky (2000) found a recursive formula for the number of equivalence classes of size 1 only, and using a computer was able to calculate the ratio of the number of size 1 classes to total ADGs for n up to 200.
Methods for computing the number of unlabeled graphs have been found by Redfield (1927) and P6lya (1937). For graphs with 10 or fewer vertices, these numbers have

Parts of this scheme are not new (Read 1978; Colbourn & Read 1979), but this combination and the addition of the following rules greatly increase the speed of the canonical configuration testing and do not appear to have been described before.

The unlabeled graphs were generated using an "orderly algorithm" as first described by Read (1978). An orderly algorithm generates a list of non-equivalent items in problems where isomorphic items must be eliminated, but does so without requiring comparison to the list of already generated items.

metadata.abstractText: Graphical Markov models determined by acyclic digraphs (ADGs), also called directed acyclic graphs (DAOs), are widely studied in statistics, computer science (as Bayesian networks), operations research (as influence diagrams), and many related fields. Because different ADOs may determine the same Markov equivalence class, it long has been of interest to determine the efficiency gained in model specification and search by working directly with Markov equivalence classes of ADOs rather than with ADOs themselves. A computer program was written to enumerate the equivalence classes of ADG models as specified by Pearl & Verma's equivalence criterion. The program counted equivalence classes for models up to and including I 0 vertices. The ratio of numbers of classes to ADGs appears to approach an asymptote of about 0.2 67. Classes were analyzed according to number of edges and class size. By edges, the distribution of number of classes approaches a Gaussian shape. By class size, classes of size 1 are most common, with the proportions for larger sizes initially decreasing but then following a more irregular pattern. The maximum number of classes generated by any undirected graph was found to increase approximately factorially. The program also includes a new variation of orderly algorithm for generating undirected graphs.
